newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Western analysts see rising U.S.-Russia fund flow.
newsitem.headline: Western analysts see rising U.S.-Russia fund flow.

text.p: U.S. investment in Russia will jump in the next few years as investors follow a trend to move funds out of the U.S. and into well-performing emerging markets, Western bankers said on Thursday.
William Donaldson, a founder of and senior adviser at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette investment bank, predicted that the U.S. could invest close to $600 million overseas in the next three years.
He told a news conference the bank calculated portfolios which average five percent foreign exposure would move to 10-12 percent in "a very short period of time".
"How much of that is coming to Russia? -- I would say a good portion," he told a news conference.

Bank of New York Vice President Christopher Sturdy, who heads the bank's programme of American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) for Eastern and Western Europe, said that $3.6 billion had been invested in Russian equity via ADRs in the last 15 months.
ADRs allow allow foreign trading of local issues.
Richard Bernard, Executive Vice President of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), said natural resources, telecoms and power companies would lead the move towards foreign listings.
"We could easily have four more Russian companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange during 1997 and over the next 3-5 years we could easily see 20-25 Russian companies listed."
Full listing and new capital raising on the NYSE through level three ADRs has only been accomplished by Vimpelcom cellular phone operator.
Salomon Brothers in a recent paper said likely level three issuers in 1997 were oil companies LUKoil and Chernogorneft and Rostelekom long distance phone company.
It said companies which could issue in 1998 were oil companies Tatneft, Surgutneftegaz and Purneftegaz and power utilities Mosenergo and Irkutskenergo.
